title: 107_s3047
content:
The "Idaho Panhandle National Forest Improvement Act of 2002" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture and addresses the sale or exchange of administrative sites. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange National Forest System land and improvements under certain conditions. This includes specific parcels like Granite/Reeder Bay and North South Ski area. The descriptions can be modified for accuracy, and consideration is required for any sale or exchange. Consideration for the sale or exchange of National Forest System land must be equal to market value and may include cash or land with improvements. Any sale or exchange is subject to applicable laws, and valuation is determined by an appraisal meeting Federal standards. The Secretary can accept cash payments exceeding 25% of land value in exchanges. Offers for land sale or exchange can be solicited and rejected if deemed inadequate. Land under subsection (a) can be sold publicly or privately, including at auction, following determined terms and procedures. The Secretary has the authority to determine terms, conditions, and procedures that are in the best interests of the United States. SEC. 4. DISPOSITION OF FUNDS.

The Secretary shall deposit proceeds from sales or exchanges in the fund established under the Sisk Act. Funds can be used for constructing a new ranger station in the Silver Valley portion of the Panhandle National Forest or for other facilities in the same forest if there is an excess amount.

SEC. 5. CONSTRUCTION OF NEW ADMINISTRATIVE FACILITIES. The Secretary is authorized to acquire, construct, or rehabilitate the ranger station using funds from section 4(b) and additional funds if needed. Proceeds from land sales under this Act cannot be distributed to States or counties. Agriculture Property Management Regulations do not apply to land disposition or actions under this Act. Lands acquired by the Secretary must be managed according to the Weeks Law. The Weeks Law (16 U.S.C. 480 et seq.) and other laws apply to the National Forest System. Public land orders withdrawing land described in section 3(a) are revoked. All land described in section 3(a) is withdrawn from mining laws. Authorization of appropriation is granted to carry out this Act.
